text: Maybe COVID is weighing the salaries down but they are very similar to what I had to work with 3 years ago when I was running a quant team and I was struggling to compete for top tier talent with the likes of Smart Odds

text: I am just basing those 2 betting analyst roles on my first ever grad role as a junior statistician in London a stone's throw from Kings X paying £20K and that was exactly 20 years ago. After jumping ship into software dev a couple of years later I never kept track on statistician/analyst salaries but low 20s seems on the low end to me. Especially now undergrads have to pay full whack fees on their degrees. My first year as an undergrad was 1993 and the fees were paid and max student loan for the year was £800. I was very lucky given what they squeeze out of kids these days. Having worked in a university (a shit one admittedly) I have seen first hand how they view education purely as a business and pull stunts to make their figures look better to secure more money instead of actions in the best interest of the students. But I am ranting off a tangent so will stop now.

text: I would say so <@U01C12ZEADQ>. I struggled 20 years ago but I took it as my first "proper" job after getting my masters. Sometimes you need to do that to get a foot in the door and some "real" experience as the first rung on career ladder. It was tough but I also wasn't saddled with £30K of debt like most grads are these days. Not really sure who a job like that is targeted at to be honest.

text: Yeah I suppose employers can be picky. Trouble is though that people often move on fast from these type of positions unless there is a serious salary increase after a short time period. In my experience interviewing and recommending candidates for positions you can normally spot the types who are going to use it for 6 months to piggyback a higher salary elsewhere. I suppose a company's skill in staff retention cannot be assessed from starting salary offers though.

text: Yeah but look  not paying 'too much' somebody on first experience, fine, but I think there would be some reasonable lower bounds on the fact that living in/around London is expensive as shit. Considering these guys I don't think they lack money... I understand the market rules but that's where you need to be a bit better than "just watching the market rules" .. it's still people.

text: I agree <@U01C12ZEADQ>. Chances are all you will attract to the role are fresh grads recently spat out of university still living at home with parents. Not sure how you could afford to live in London or commute from outside on that wage. I live in commuter belt territory and its about £5K for a season ticket on the train. But some places are strange. There are companies that are notorious for only taking the best candidates - even companies that are nothing special or even interesting to work for. They have vacancies that go unfilled for months because of this. I suspect that some of those advertised "Betting Analyst" jobs are not much more than some kind of admin related positions with the candidate learning the good stuff on the job.
